newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybeans end down on speculative selling.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybeans end down on speculative selling.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended mostly down on Wednesday on speculative selling mainly from retail investors, traders said.
The most activly traded January 1998 contract ended at 3,316 yuan ($400) per tonne, losing 11 yuan. It opened at 3,318 yuan, hitting an intraday high of 3,319 and a low of 3,315.
July fell 75 yuan to 3,205, September 19 to 3,300, November rose 23 to 3,370 and the March 1998 contract dropped five yuan to 3,365.
Combined volume rose to 19,200 tonnes from 17,700.
Soybeans opened lower and moved in a narrow range for most of the session, traders said.
"Retail investors recently became major traders on the market with most hot speculative money flowing into the booming stock market," one trader said.
"Their speculative selling and profit-taking dominated today's trading," he said.
Traders said they expected soybeans to continue moving in a range of 3,300 to 3,400 yuan in the short term.
